items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This flood alert has been issued as strong winds are expected to cause overtopping waves and spray along the coast. Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Flooding of coastal roads, promenades and coastal footpaths is expected between 9:00 AM and 7:00 PM on Thursday 17/11/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Thursday 17/11/2022. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. The area of concern is expected to be at Sandsend between 10:00am and 1:30pm on 17/11/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated in the afternoon 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

Thursday's tide from 9:00am to midnight on 17/11/2022 is higher than normal due to winds and large waves. Areas most at risk include the lifeboat station, north pier, and south pier at Bridlington. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated in the afternoon on 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, avoid low lying footpaths, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Further rainfall is forecast during the day on Thursday which will keep river levels high. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Thursday 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Alert for the River Rye catchment has been issued. River levels are forecast to rise on the river Rye catchment due to rainfall expected in the early hours of Thursday 17/11/2022. Areas most at risk include land around the river Rye and its tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck and Spittle Beck, including properties at Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. In these areas, flooding of land and roads is possible from 6:00 AM on Thursday 17/11/2022.  River levels could remain high throughout Thursday. Further rainfall over the coming days will mean river levels are likely to fluctuate. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 17/11/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

The River Uck is high, but now falling. Flood impacts will continue to affect fields, gardens and rural roads throughout Thursday, particularly in Isfield, near Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge, while the river slowly returns nearer to a normal level. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday, which should allow minor flood impacts to lessen by Friday. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please keep flood protection products installed Thursday, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
We have seen heavy rainfall across the area overnight into Thursday 17 November. This has caused the Upper Colne at Colney Heath to rise.
River levels have now peaked and are dropping down again.
There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river tonight and into tomorrow morning. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
No flooding to properties is currently expected.
Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
We expect to remove this flood alert by this evening.

River levels remain high on the Paxcroft Brook in Trowbridge and further rain is forecast for Wednesday evening.  This may cause river levels to rise over night Wednesday and into Thursday morning.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated on the morning of Thursday 17th November, or sooner if the situation changes.

The River Uck is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, over half a month's rainfall (50mm) has been recorded at Buxted. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 23:00 16/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens and riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 09:00 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Thursday evening. River levels could end up similar to the peaks of last week. Riverside properties in Buxted are encouraged to install flood protection products if you have them and take steps to reduce the impact of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today until this evening, 17 November, along the River Teise around Lamberhurst. Rainfall is expected to clear this morning and weather conditions should then remain dry until Saturday 19 November. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are assessing the flood impacts from this event. Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated by 9pm on 17 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is very high but is now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect properties close to Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. The A281 at Mock Bridge is likely to remain impassable today (Thursday 17/11/2022). There will also be extensive water in fields and flooding of gardens. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday. The river level should continue to slowly fall but will not return nearer to normal until Friday afternoon. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Some roads may be impassable, so please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 17/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is very high and rising. In the last 48 hours, more than half a month’s rain (70mm) has been recorded at Knighton. By 04:00 (17/11/2022), the river will flood gardens in Alverstone and Langbridge, and the main road at Alverstone. At Sandown, Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will continue to flood, and levels will be high at Sandown Bridge, the sewage treatment plant and Fort Holiday Park. By 02:00 (17/11/2022), gardens will flood in Nicholas Close. Property flooding is a possibility throughout the Eastern Yar. We will issue a Flood Warning if we think this will occur. Dry weather is expected for the rest of the night. The river will peak at Alverstone at around 16:00 (17/11/2022), and on Thursday night at Sandown. We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to help reduce water levels across Brading Marshes. We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please take action now to ensure you can protect your property. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday 17/11/2022 or sooner if required.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Blackwater and The Cove Brook as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (17/11/2022).
The weather forecast is for a mostly dry day.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high and rising between Scayne's Hill and Barcombe. Flood impacts will continue to affect isolated properties, rural roads and fields. Flood Warnings remain in force in many communities. The river has begun to slowly fall near Ardingly, but might not begin to fall until midday Thursday downstream, possibly 15:00 17/11/2022 in Barcombe. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday, the River Ouse should return nearer to a normal level by the weekend. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Some roads affected by flooding will be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Barcombe Mills Road, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: River Teise and Lesser Teise area from Horsmonden to Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels are high as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today, Thursday 17 November and will continue overnight. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Teise and Lesser Teise. Rainfall is expected to clear this morning and weather conditions should then remain dry until Saturday 19 November.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Avoid walking or driving through floodwater and please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  This message will be updated by 9pm on Thursday 17 November or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising in Alfriston. Flooding will continue to affect North Street, Litlington Road, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers in Hellingly are high, but now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Flood impacts should soon ease on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. The river level in Alfriston should begin to fall by 15:00 Thursday 17/11/2022. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday. In Hellingly, river levels could return nearer to normal by Friday afternoon. In Alfriston river levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until Sunday. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including North Street Alfriston and Church Road, Hellingly. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 17/11/2022.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours until midday on 17 November 2022. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely for the rest of today and overnight tonight. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The weather forecast is for light rain and strong winds through today and further unsettled spells tomorrow. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.message: River levels are continuing to rise as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land and towpaths is expected to continue today, Thursday 17 November between Wateringbury and Maidstone Town Centre, particularly in the Lockmeadow area. Rainfall is expected to clear this morning and weather conditions should remain dry until Saturday 19 November. We expect river levels to remain high through until Friday evening, 18 November. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated by 9pm on 17 November 2022, or as the situation changes

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high but now falling. Flooding will continue to affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, as well as there being extensive water in fields, gardens and on rural roads. The Bull River through Hellingly has already fallen significantly from its overnight peak, only minor residual flood impacts are expected on Mill Lane Hellingly. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday. River levels should continue to slowly fall, returning nearer to normal by Friday afternoon. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Some roads including Mill Road and Church Road may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 17/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Barcombe. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 23:00 16/11/2022 flooding will be extensive through fields. Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane are likely to be impassable. The Anchor Inn is expected to flood and water could approach properties at Barcombe Mills. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 17:00 17/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels could end up similar to the peaks of last week. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.  We expect river levels to remain fall through the day and no flooding to properties is currently expected.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated if the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Cowbeech. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 02:00 17/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 22:00 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until the weekend. River levels could end up similar to the recent peaks of last week. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 17/11/2022.

Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon.
River levels are high and forecast to rise further.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels at Scrasebridge and West Common Streams have now fallen from their peak. River levels should return to near normal by Thursday afternoon. However, it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

The Western Rother is high and rising between Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. Flood water will continue to affect properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth, with minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens along the whole Western Rother. Flooding could affect properties at Coultershaw Bridge. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday. River levels should begin to fall at Lodsbridge by 16:00 17/11/2022 and in Fittleworth by 04:00 18/11/2022 but will remain higher than normal until the weekend. Between Liss and Midhurst, the Western Rother has already begun to slowly fall. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Please plan to avoid driving through roads prone to flooding, including Lower Street through Fittleworth. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 17/11/2022.

The Langney Haven is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, nearly half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Folkington. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 21:00 16/11/2022 minor flooding could affect gardens of properties at Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park will also be affected. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 05:00 17/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until next week. River levels could end up similar to the peaks seen last week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles Gate to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high but are now slowly falling. The river in Crowhurst did not rise as high as we thought overnight. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect Crowhurst Recreation Ground, gardens in Crowhurst, rural roads, fields and the Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday. The river should return nearer to normal in Crowhurst by Friday. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please keep flood protection products close by, in readiness for next week as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 17/11/2022.

The River Arun is high and rising between Newbridge near Billingshurst and Pulborough. From 12:00 on Thursday (17/11/2022) flooding could affect properties at Pallingham Lock and the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst. Between Horsham and Wanford, river levels are stable or slowly falling. Minor flood impacts will continue along the length of the Upper Arun, affecting fields, gardens and rural roads. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday, but the River Arun near Pallingham Lock is unlikely to begin to fall until 02:00 on Friday (18/11/2022) and might not return nearer to normal until the weekend. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please keep flood protection products installed if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 22:00 17/11/2022.

The River Lox is high and rising. Over the last two days, more than half a month's rainfall (60mm) has been recorded at Chiddingfold. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens along the length of the river Lox. From 10:00 17/11/2022 flood water could approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood and isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold. Flood water may also affect riverside properties on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday. The River Lox should begin to fall by midday Thursday morning, but will not return nearer to a normal level until Friday. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please continue to operate private water control structures to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar at Alverstone is high and rising. Over half a month’s rain (70mm) has been recorded in Wroxall since Tuesday morning (15/11/2022). Currently the access track to Horringford will be flooded, restricting access. Golf Links Road, cycle tracks and footpaths across the Upper Yar Valley will be impassable. From 12:00 midday (17/11/2022) in Alverstone, the main road will flood near the main road bridge. Water will begin to surround property in Alverstone and Langbridge, where property flooding is possible. Rain has now cleared the area. At Alverstone, the river will rise until 16:00 (17/11/2022). It will remain at its peak for several hours before the level begins to fall. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. If you have it, please install flood protection equipment now and leave it in place until at least Friday (18/11/2022). This Flood Warning will be updated by 19:00 on Thursday 17/11/2022.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the Hoe Stream at Woking  as a result of recent heavy rainfall over the last two days. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected today (17/11/2022). The weather forecast is for a mostly dry day. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and slowly rising. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Very little rainfall is forecast for Thursday and Friday. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 on 17/11/2022 but will remain higher than normal until next week. In Barnham, river levels are already falling and minor flood impacts there should reduce. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 on 17/11/2022.

In Arundel, only minimal flood impacts are currently expected. Very little rain is forecast over the next 2 days. However, the river is unlikely to begin to fall until 02:00 Friday 18/11/2022, and not returning nearer to a normal level until next week. River levels could potentially rise as high as February 2020. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 18:00 17/11/2022.

Areas most at risk are roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur. Further heavy showers are expected over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible during the afternoon of Wednesday 16th November into Thursday Morning. 
 
Following heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours catchments in this area remain wet and sensitive to any further rainfall.

During Wednesday afternoon, a further low-pressure system will affect this area, bringing heavy rain and strong winds.  Up to 35mm of rainfall forecast for some locations. 
 
River levels are forecast to rise in response. The highest levels are forecast during Wednesday night into Thursday morning.  The main areas of concern are low lying land and roads close to the river.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor river levels and issue Flood Warnings if required.  Trash screens and blockages have been cleared in this area. This message will be updated on Thursday morning (17/11/22) or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and river levels are below levels of concern.

The Western Rother is high and rising. Flooding will continue to affect Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. The B2138 Lower Street road over the river at Fittleworth could be impassable and there will be extensive water in fields. Very little rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday. The Western Rother should begin to fall by 02:00 Friday (18/11/2022), in Fittleworth. However, river levels will be higher than normal until next week. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Some roads, including the B2138 through Fittleworth, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 17/11/2022.

The River Adur is high, but slowly falling. Minor flood impacts affecting locations near Slaughter Bridge on Coolham Road, as well as isolated farm buildings, fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield should ease by Thursday evening. River levels will remain higher than normal until Friday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Coolham Road at Slaughter Bridge. The next three days are currently predicted to remain dry. However, it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 20:00 on Thursday 17/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected overnight at Tonbridge playing fields, town centre car parks, Postern Lane through to Tudeley, East Peckham and The Lees at Yalding. Further heavy rain is forecast later this evening on Wednesday 16 November and will clear around 1am. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday 17 November.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Thursday 17 November or as the situation changes.

The Powdermill Stream is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, 35mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill, which is a lot in a short period. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 22:00 16/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads and a small number of riverside properties in Crowhurst; on Forewood Lane and properties between The Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 10:00 17/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels will end up higher than the peaks of last week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 17/11/2022.

From 23:00 16/11/2022 flood water will affect properties of Freshfield Mill Farm, Freshmill and Millers Cottages on Sloop Lane and Bridge Cottage, Sheffield Park. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will be affected and potentially impassable. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels could end up higher than the peaks of last week. Some roads including Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding suggested in this message. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

From 03:00 17/11/2022 flood water will affect fields, gardens, rural roads and properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham. Flood water could affect properties and the A285 at Coultershaw Bridge, near Petworth. Properties on the Lod could also be affected, including those near Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane, and at Halfway Bridge. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river might not begin to fall until 22:00 17/11/2022, and will be higher than normal until the weekend. River levels will end up higher than the peaks of Wednesday morning. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Lodsbridge, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

We expect the river level to return to normal later today (17/11/2022) and any minor flood impacts should significantly reduce over the next few days. The water level in the River Lymington at Brockenhurst is high and rising. In the last 8 hours, 24mm of rain has been recorded in Brockenhurst. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. From 23:30 on 16/11/2022, the river will be much higher than normal and drainage ditches through the New Forest will be flooding land and roads. It will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 10 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. Lighter rain is forecast over the next 3 hours which means that the river will remain high until at least 08:00 on 17/11/2022 before water levels fall. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Watersplashes will deepen over the next 24 hours. Do not drive through floodwater. This Flood Alert will be updated at 12:00 on 17/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Ardingly. From 05:00 17/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens and affect properties at Bridge Cottage and Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 17/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until Friday morning. River levels could end up similar to those seen in March 2020. Riverside properties at Dean's Water Mill and Lindfield Bridge are encouraged to install flood protection products if you have them and take steps to reduce the impact of flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 2 days, more than half a month's rain (78mm) has been recorded at Ardingly. From 04:00 17/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens and affect properties at Slaugham Place, near Old Hall on Brantridge Lane. Only very small amounts of rain are forecast over the next 2 days. The river should begin to fall by Thursday afternoon and should return to normal from Friday. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Riverside properties are encouraged to install flood protection products if you have them and take steps to reduce the impact of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar at Sandown is high and rising. Over half a month’s rain (70mm) has been recorded in Knighton since Tuesday morning (15/11/2022). Currently, there is extensive out of bank flooding throughout the Yar Valley. Moreton Common Road and Golf Links Road are flooded. Today (17/11/2022), Fort Holiday Park and Sandown sewage works could flood as ditches struggle to drain to the main river. The next high tide at Cowes is expected at 04:30 (17/11/2022). For about 4 hours after high water, property flooding is possible at Nicholas Close, Brading. Rain has now cleared the area. At Sandown, the river is expected to continue rising until Thursday night. We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to manage water levels across Brading marshes. However, the neap tide cycle will restrict the amount of water which can drain from the river for the next 4 days. If you have it, please install flood protection now. We recommend leaving it in place until at least Friday (18/11/2022). This Flood Warning will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday 17/11/2022.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the River Great Stour, particularly between Wye and Canterbury. No further rainfall is forecast for today, but we expect river levels to peak later this evening at Wye, and on Friday morning in Canterbury, 18/11/22.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 

Please consider avoiding low lying footpaths near local watercourses between Ashford and Canterbury. This message will be updated by 9pm on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning is in force due to low pressure and strong winds which are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast, on Thursday morning, 17/11/22 between 11:30am and 1:30pm. 

Hazardous conditions might extend 2 hours either side of the high tide. The area most at risk is Sandsend, including the A174. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous with debris. 

You can check flood warnings and alerts on the GOV.UK website or via Floodline number 0345 988 1188. We are monitoring the situation closely. This message will be updated by 6pm Thursday 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
